Context: The results showed that DSS-induced colitis was aggravated in C6deficient mice compared with wild-type (WT) mice, as represented by the markedly greater weight loss, higher disease activity index (DAI), shortened colon length, more severe histological injury with increased epithelial ulcerations, and massively increased infiltration of leukocytes accompanied by much higher myeloperoxidase (MPO) levels in local inflammatory colonic sites.
We found that murine acute DSS-induced coliis was aggravated in C6-deficient mice compared with wild-type WT) mice, indicating the protective role of MAC in IBD. .
